Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

As I had posted earlier, NEAT does great in robot control domain. 
I had tr=
ied it out on a from scratch simulation, and had nice results (atleast for =
gathering, flocking and searching). 
It did much better than a technique th=
at used to evolve assembly code for the robot controller. 
Although, you ar=
e right in saying that transfering the code to physical robots should requi=
re more evolutions on the hardware itself. 
Although, what I got from Nolfi=
's book was, that if one can tweak the simulation after many cycles of hard=
ware and software runs, it might be possible to just transfer the controlle=
rs from the software to the hardware and make it all run fine.
I believe go=
od simulators for Khepera are made such.

Regards,
- Umer

  ----- Original=
 Message ----- 
  From: Kenneth Stanley 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent=
: Tuesday, February 17, 2004 4:20 AM
  Subject: [neat] Re: New NEAT Paper

=

  Hi Derek, I wrote my robot control code off of previously
  existing Khe=
pera simulator software.  So the core of the
  code is from that, although =
it's been much expanded and
  changed.  I think it's definitely a good idea=
 to take 
  advantage of available robot simulators, and NEAT should
  do q=
uite well with most any realistic robot simulator.
  The one concern is tha=
t some simulators are not built for
  training, which means that they may n=
ot let you turn off
  the graphics or run in "fast forward" mode.  If you
 =
 can't do that, evolution will take forever because each
  trial has to tak=
e place in slow real-world physical time.
  So you should make sure for any=
 simulator that it allows
  you to run the simulator without the graphics, =
or at least
  with the graphics in extreme fast forward.

  To answer your =
second question, if NEAT is trained on a
  realistic simulation of a real p=
hysical robot (e.g. Khepera)
  then the results should be transferable.  In=
 practice, the
  transfer will not be a perfect and a few extra generations=

  of refinement evolution in the real world may be necessary.
  Nolfi and =
Floreano's book, "Evolutionary Robotics," addresses
  the issues of crossov=
er to the real world in detail.  The
  main problem is that once you enter =
the real-world, everything
  is constrained by real-world time and so evolu=
tion must
  be necessity proceed at a much slower rate.

  I think trying y=
our ANJI NEAT (hmm...how to say it?) with
  robot simulators would be great=
.  NEAT is known to be good
  in that kind of domain.

  ken

  --- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
  > --- Kenneth Stanle=
y <kstanley@c...> wrote:
  > > Some of you may have read our previous Tech =
Report,
  > > "Competitive
  > > Coevolution through Evolutionary Complexif=
ication." 
  > > That paper has
  > > now been replaced with a much-updated=
 journal paper
  > > in the Journal of
  > > Artificial Intelligence Resear=
ch (JAIR), by the same
  > > title.  The newer
  > > paper has been expande=
d and updated, and includes
  > > significantly more
  > > experimental res=
ults.  
  > 
  > Cool...thanks for the update, Ken.
  > 
  > I'm interested=
 to read this updated paper.
  > 
  > I had a question about how you implem=
ented your robot
  > simulation.  Did you do all the simulation stuff from
=
  > scratch?
  > 
  > Though we're primarily concentrating on game domains,=

  > we've been looking at robot control as well.  There
  > are a few good=
 opensource robot simulators out there. 
  > In Java, there are KSIM and Te=
amBots:
  > 
  > http://ehrg.cs.wright.edu/ksim/ksim.html
  > http://www.te=
ambots.org/
  > 
  > I had previously looked at JRobots, but it is not
  > =
opensource, and the restrictions for developing the
  > bots is prohibitive=
 for research.
  > 
  > KSIM models Khepera robots and TeamBots models Noma=
d
  > and Cye robots.  TeamBots also includes a SoccerBots
  > package whic=
h pits teams of five against one another,
  > and it includes a fairly larg=
e range of hard-coded
  > strategies.
  > 
  > Our focus right now is tryin=
g to finally get our NEAT
  > implementation released (we've settled on the=
 name of
  > ANJI--Another NEAT Java Implementation), but we'd like
  > to =
look down the road at a variety of domains to
  > extend it, and robot simu=
lations seem like a pretty
  > interesting domain (but we'd rather not code=

  > everything from scratch if we can help it).
  > 
  > I was also wonder=
ing if any of the NEAT control
  > algorithms that you evolved for your rob=
ot control
  > experiments might be portable to a physical robot.  I
  > no=
tice a professor named Peter Stone there at UT
  > Austin who seems to be i=
nvolved in RoboCup competition
  > with both wheeled and legged robots, bot=
h physical and
  > simulated.  Is there any crossover in what you guys
  > =
do?
  > 
  > Derek
  > 
  > __________________________________
  > Do you Y=
ahoo!?
